Determination and tracing of active and dormant propagation chains in 1-hexene polymerization with supported Ziegler-Natta catalyst Pengjia Yang Investigation Methodology Data curation Formal analysis Visualization Writing - original draft 1 Wentao Zhong Investigation Methodology Data curation Formal analysis Visualization Writing - original draft 1 Baiyu Jiang Investigation Resources Software Validation Biao Zhang Investigation Resources Software Validation Zhisheng Fu Conceptualization Formal analysis Data curation Project administration Resources Writing - review & editing * Zhiqiang Fan Funding acquisition Project administration Resources Supervision Writing - review & editing * MOE Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Synthesis and Functionalization, Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China MOE Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Synthesis and Functionalization Department of Polymer Science and Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract Propagation chains with 1,2 and 2,1 last-inserted monomer unit in 1-hexene polymerization with MgCl2-supported Ziegler-Natta catalysts were quench-labeled by thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride, and the two kinds of 2-thenoyl-labeled chain ends were determined by 1H NMR analysis. The number of labeled chains was noticeably smaller than the number of dead chains formed by chain transfer with alkylaluminum cocatalyst, and grew with time more slowly than the latter, showing that side reactions between the quencher and Al-polymeryl moieties are negligible. The active sites with 2,1 last-inserted monomer were halted in dormant state, which lead to their gradual accumulation in the 30 s polymerization process. The catalyst containing phthalate type internal donor has higher percentage of dormant sites as compared with the catalyst containing diol ester. The combination of acyl chloride quench-labeling and 1H NMR analysis forms a reliable and easily accessible method of tracing and characterizing active sites in transition metal catalyzed olefin polymerization. Keywords α-Olefin Polymerization MgCl2-supported ZN catalyst Kinetics Quench-Labeling 1 Introduction Stereoselective polymerizations of α-olefins (propylene, 1-butene, etc.) with Ziegler-Natta (ZN) catalysts have the second largest share in industrial production of synthetic polymers [1]. Beside high stereoregularity, the polymers synthesized with supported ZN catalysts contain exceedingly low amount of regioerrors (head-to-head and tail-to-tail enchainments) that are hardly detectable in conventional 13C NMR analysis [2,3]. This high regioregularity is closely related with the crystallization behavior and mechanical properties of isotactic polypropylene (i-PP) [4]. However, many literatures show that the high regioregularity of i-PP does not excludes regio-irregular propylene insertion in metal-polymer bond of the active site, since a high proportion of propagation chains with 2,1 last-inserted propylene unit have been experimentally detected, and further α-olefin insertion in the metal-polymeryl bond with a 2,1 last-inserted propylene unit is extremely slow [5–10]. The active sites with a 2,1 last-inserted α-olefin unit are actually halted in dormant state. As the result, formation of regioerrors is largely avoided. Similar phenomena have been observed in polymerization of higher α-olefins like 1-butene and 1-hexene [11,12]. As the dormant sites formed after 2,1-insertion can recover from the dormancy by adding hydrogen or ethylene in the polymerization system [7,9,13], regioselectivity of ZN catalysts has become one of the key factors to determine the polymerization kinetics (including hydrogen response and comonomer activation effect) and polymer chain structure. To better understand the polymerization mechanism and the relationship between catalyst structure and its catalysis behaviors, it is of great importance to develop methods to determine and trace the dormant sites formed by 2,1-insertion in α-olefin polymerization. Several approaches have been explored for studying regioirregular enchainments in propylene polymerization [9,10,14]. By copolymerizing propylene with small amount of ethylene-[1-13C] and characterizing the copolymer chain structure, Busico et al. determined the fraction of 2,1-insertion in propylene polymerization with supported Ziegler-Natta catalysts, and studied relationship between internal electron donor in the catalyst and regioselectivity of chain propagation [9]. By 13C NMR analysis on the end groups of PP produced in quenched-flow polymerization, the formation and transformation of propagation chains with either 1,2 (primary) or 2,1 (secondary) last-inserted propylene unit in the initial 2 s reaction period were directly traced [10]. However, since these methods require use of expensive isotope-enriched reagents or special NMR instrument equipped with cryoprobes, their wide application suffers from many practical limitations. Theoretically, it is possible to detect the two kinds of metal-polymeryl bonds by quench-labeling the active species and quantitatively determine the labeled chain ends using 1H or 13C NMR analysis. Various quench-labeling methods have been reported in the past decades for counting the active species in metal catalyzed olefin polymerization [14–22]. However, the quenching agents that simultaneously label metal-polymeryl bonds of the active sites and Al-polymeryl moieties formed by chain transfer with alkylaluminum cocatalyst cannot be used for determining the propagation chain ends when the latter are present in the reaction system. Considering the remarkably higher efficiency of 1H NMR analysis than 13C NMR, the method will be more accessible when the labeled chain ends with 1,2 and 2,1 last-inserted monomer unit can be clearly distinguished and quantified in the polymer’s 1H NMR spectrum. Of course, high reliability and selectivity of the quench-labeling method are prerequisites for its application in tracing the chemical structure of propagation chain ends. In our previous work, a quench-labeling method using acyl chloride as the quenching agent has been developed [22]. The acyl chloride quencher has been found to quickly react with the metal-polymeryl bond of the active sites, meanwhile the Al-polymeryl bond was inactive to acyl chloride when the acyl chloride/Al molar ratio was larger than 1. According to the present results of characterizing the products of quenching reaction, the mechanism of quench-labeling by acyl chlorides can be described in Scheme 1 (using thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride as the quencher and 1-hexene as the monomer). If the labeled chain ends with the 1,2 and 2,1 last-inserted monomer unit (P1 and P2) can be separately quantified by 1H NMR analysis, this method will be readily applicable for tracing the dormant sites formed by 2,1-insertion in α-olefin polymerization. In this work, the quench-labeling method based on thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride (TPCC) quencher was applied to 1-hexene polymerization with supported Ziegler-Natta catalyst, and the regioselectivity of monomer insertion was studied by 1H NMR analysis on the labeled chain ends for the first time. 2 Experimental section All operations with moisture and oxygen sensitive reagents were conducted under N2 using standard Schlenk techniques or glove box unless otherwise noted. 2.1 Materials Two commercial MgCl2-supported ZN catalyst Cat. 1 (MgCl2/Di/TiCl4, Di = diisobutyl phthalate, Ti content =2.7 wt%, provided by SINOPEC) and Cat. 2 (MgCl2/Di/TiCl4, Di = diol ester [23], Ti content =2.7 wt%, provided by SINOPEC) were used for polymerization. Triethylaluminum (TEA, purchased from Albemarle Co.) was used as received and diluted in n-heptane before use. 1-Hexene (Alfa Aesar Co.) was purified by passing through columns of molecular sieves and diluted in n-heptane before use. Thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride (TPCC, 98 %, J&K Scientific Co.) was distilled and diluted with n-heptane to 2 M before use. n-Heptane was first dried over 4A molecular sieves under dry N2 and then refluxed over Na before use. Isobutyllithium (J&K Scientific Co.), sec-butyllithium (Aladdin Industrial Co.), methyl-2-thienyl ketone (Adamas Reagent Ltd.) and 1-iodoethane (Adamas Reagent Ltd.) were used as received. All other chemicals were obtained commercially and used without further purification unless otherwise stated. 2.2 Precontact, polymerization and quench-labeling 1-Hexene polymerization in n-heptane with Cat. 1 (or Cat. 2) was carried out in Schlenk flask at 40 °C under nitrogen atmosphere for different durations (t p). Considering the very short reaction durations, 3 g catalyst was used in each polymerization run to obtain enough polymer for characterization. Calculated amount of reagent was added in the order of n-heptane, TEA and the catalyst to form a reaction suspension with total volume of 141 mL, [Ti] =12 mmol/L and [Al] =120 mmol/L. Precontact started after the catalyst was added into flask under stirring. After 10 min, stirring was stopped and the reaction system was kept still for 10 min, and then 90 % of the supernatant was removed, after which 39 ml of n-heptane was added into the remaining suspension to make a solution with [Ti] =30 mmol/L and [Al] =30 mmol/L (total volume =56 ml). Polymerization was started after adding 1-hexene (0.712 g) into the flask under stirring. After designed reaction duration, calculated amount of TPCC solution was injected into the reactor at TPCC/Al (molar ratio) = 2 to quench-label the propagation chains, and the reactor content was further stirred at 40 °C for 5 min. Subsequently isopropanol/HCl mixture (95/5) was added to decompose the catalyst, and the polymer was precipitated with excess of isopropanol. Then the deposited polymer was thoroughly purified by repeated dissolution-precipitation operation for three times, and then dried in vacuum at 50 °C. 2.3 Synthesis of alkyl thienyl ketones Four model alkyl thienyl ketones (M1-M4 in Scheme 2 ) were synthesized according to the method of Abele et al [24]. M1 and M3 were prepared by reaction of TPCC with isobutyllithium and sec-butyllithium, respectively, M2 and M4 were prepared by reaction of methyl 2-thienyl ketone and iodoethane. 2.4 Characterization 1H NMR spectra of quenched poly(1-hexene) were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE III 400 spectrometer operating at 400 MHz in CDCl3 with pulse relaxation delay of 1 s, and 1024 scans were accumulated for each sample at 25 °C. 1H NMR spectra of model ketones were recorded on the same spectrometer operating at 400 MHz, and 16 scans were accumulated. 1H NMR spectrum of a typical poly(1-hexene) sample prepared by 1-hexene polymerization with Cat. 1/TEA and quench-labeled with TPCC was recorded on a Varian Mercury 300 plus spectrometer operating at 300 MHz in 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane-d2 with pulse relaxation delay of 2 s, and 3072 scans were accumulated at 80 °C. 1H NMR spectra of a blank poly(1-hexene) terminated without quenching was recorded on an Agilent Direct Drive 2 spectrometer operating at 600 MHz, and 512 scans were accumulated at 25 °C. The spectra were obtained at 25 °C in chloroform-d, using the peak of chloroform-d (7.26 ppm) as internal reference. 13C NMR spectra of poly(1-hexene) were recorded on an Agilent Direct Drive 2 spectrometer operating at 150 MHz, and 2000 scans were accumulated at 25 °C. Chloroform-d was used as the solvent to prepare the polymer solution of 5 wt%. Chromium triacetyl acetonate (about 5 mg) was added in each sample to shorten the relaxation time. Broadband decoupling with a pulse delay of 5 s was employed. Sulfur content of each quenched polymer was determined by a YHTS-2000 UV fluorescence sulfur analyzer with a lower detection limit of 0.05 ppm (Jiangyan Yinhe Instrument Co., Jiangyan, China). 2 − 5 mg polymer sample (weighed to ±0.01 mg) was used in each measurement, and the average value of three parallel measurements was taken as the sulfur content. Only trace amount of sulfur was detected in blank samples that were not quenched by TPCC and purified in the same procedures, thus 0 ppm of blank sulfur level was adopted. Molecular weight and molecular weight distribution (M w/M n) of the obtained poly(1-hexene) was determined by gel permeation chromatograph (GPC) on a PL GPC220 instrument equipped with refractive index detector (Agilent Technologies) and two PL gel 5 m MIXED-C columns using polystyrene (PS) standards and THF eluent at a flow rate of 1.0 ml/min at 40 °C. Molecular weight was corrected by Mark-Houwink equation with Mark-Houwink constants K PS = 1.10 × 10−4, α PS = 0.725, K PH = 2.32 × 10−4, α PH = 0.69. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) observations of the catalyst particles were made with a Hitachi-4800 SEM. Micrographs were taken at 3 kV acceleration voltage. Before the SEM observations, all the sample surfaces were sputter-coated with a thin layer of gold. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the quench-labeled polymer chain ends 1-Hexene polymerization with two supported ZN catalysts (TiCl4/Di/MgCl2, Di = isobutylphthalate for Cat. 1 and diol ester for Cat. 2) in combination with Al(CH2CH3)3 (TEA) was conducted for different durations ranging from 5 to 30 s, and each polymerization run was quenched by TPCC for 5 min. To enhance the fraction of living chains in the product, the monomer/catalyst ratio was controlled at low level (1-hexene/Ti molar ratio = 12.5), and high catalyst load was applied. For the rather short polymerization durations, the catalyst was precontacted with TEA for about 25 min at 40 °C before adding 1-hexene to the reactor, with an aim to avoid effects of slow active site formation on the polymerization kinetics. The results of 1-hexene polymerization and quench-labeling are listed in Table 1 . Both catalysts rapidly initiated polymerization of 1-hexene, as the polymerization rate (R p) continuously decayed in the reaction process of 5 to 30 s. Since the monomer conversion at 30 s was lower than 30 %, the 40–80 % R p reduction from 5 s to 30 s cannot be solely attributed to the decrease of 1-hexene concentration with time. Number average molecular weight of the produced polymer was almost constant in the 30 s reaction process, meaning that life time of the propagation chains was rather short, and the polymer chain length was determined by the relative ratio of chain propagation and chain transfer reactions when the chain length is in the steady state. The quenched polymer samples were thoroughly purified, and their 1H NMR spectra were recorded. Fig. 1 shows 1H NMR spectrum of a typical polymer sample synthesized with Cat. 1/TEA for 10 s and quench-labeled with TPCC. 1H NMR spectra of all the samples in Table 1 and a blank poly(1-hexene) terminated without the quenching step are shown in Figs S1 and S2 of the Supporting information. To assign the 1H NMR signals of quench-labeled propagation chain ends P1 and P2 shown in Scheme 1, four model alkyl 2-thienyl ketones (isobutyl 2-thienyl ketone (M1), n-propyl 2-thienyl ketone (M2), 2-butyl 2-thienyl ketone (M3), 3-pentyl 2-thienyl ketone (M4)) were synthesized, and their 1H NMR spectra were recorded. M1 and M2 with a methylene connecting to thenoyl are similar to the quenched chain end P1, M3 and M4 with a methine connecting to thenoyl are similar to the quenched chain end P2. The signal of methylene protons adjacent to thenoyl in M1 and M2 appeared at 2.75 and 2.88 ppm, respectively, and the signal of methine protons adjacent to thenoyl in M3 and M4 appeared at 3.21 and 3.08 ppm, respectively (see Fig. S3 of the Supporting information). It is thus expectable that the 1H NMR signals of the methylene protons in P1 and methine proton in P2 will not overlap with each other. According to 1H NMR spectra of the model alkyl 2-thienyl ketones, the doublet peaks at 2.78 ppm and triplet peaks at 2.88 ppm in 1H NMR spectra of the quench-labeled poly(1-hexene) were assigned to methylene protons of P1 and methine proton of P2, respectively. The three peaks at 7.1, 7.6 and 7.7 ppm were assigned to protons on the thiophene ring. The slightly lower chemical shift of the methine proton of P2 than that of M4 could be attributed to difference in the alkyls connecting to the methine carbon. Replacement of a methyl (M3) by ethyl (M4) has caused evident upfield shift of the methine proton from 3.21 to 3.08 ppm, indicating that chemical shift of this kind of methine proton is sensitive to the structure of alkyls attached to the methine carbon. To further confirm the assignment of the 2.88 ppm signal to the methine proton of P2, a highly branched polyethylene (HBPE) sample was synthesized with a Brookhart type α-diimine nickel catalyst and quenched by TPCC, and 1H NMR spectrum of the HBPE was recorded to analyze the quench-labeled propagation chain ends. It was found that the sample has two overlapped multiplets at 2.89 ppm, one triplet and one quartet. The signal to noise ratio of these peaks was much higher than that of quench-labeled poly(1-hexene) shown in Fig. 1, owing to high active center concentration of the Ni catalyzed polymerization. For high quality of the 1H NMR spectrum of HBPE, we were able to make satisfactory multi-peak deconvolution of the signals around 2.9 ppm, and clearly distinguish the triplet at 2.89 ppm from the quartet at 2.89 ppm (see Figs S4-S5 in Supporting information). The two kinds of chain ends have a methylene carbon (forming a triplet) and a methine carbon (forming a sextet, but for the low signal to noise ratio, only a quartet was observed) connecting with the thenoyl, respectively (see Scheme 3 ), which are formed through chain-walking mechanism as elucidated by M. Brookhart et al. [25]. The 1H NMR analysis on quenched-labeled HBPE shows that signal of the proton of thenoyl capped methine carbon attached by a methyl and a long chain (similar to P2) appears at around 2.9 ppm. As another evidence supporting these assignments, 1H NMR spectrum of a propylene polymer synthesized with the same α-diimine nickel catalyst and quenched by TPCC was recorded, and similarly overlapped multiplets at 2.89 ppm was observed. These multiplets were also deconvoluted into a triplet at 2.89 ppm and a quartet at 2.89 ppm (see Fig. S6 in Supporting information). Because of higher branch density of the polypropylene sample (221 Branches/1000 Carbons) than that of the HBPE sample (116 Branches/1000 Carbons), relative intensity of the quartet assigned to methine proton in the polypropylene sample was much larger than that of the HBPE sample. This can be taken as a strong support for assigning the 2.88 ppm multiplets of the quenched poly(1-hexene) to methine proton of P2. Based on the multi-peak deconvolution of the signals around 2.9 ppm, the total amount of labeled chains with linear and branched ends were determined, which were found to be 10–15 % smaller than the amount of sulfur in the sample. It means that the same extent of deviation between the 1H NMR quantification and sulfur analysis existed in quench-labeling study on olefin polymerization with α-diimine nickel catalyst. The quench-labeled polymer also showed signals of thienyl protons at 7.1, 7.6 and 7.7 ppm, respectively, and the amount of thienyl group calculated based on their integrations (representing three protons) were only 10 % lower than the sum of P1 and P2 determined by the signals at 2.78 and 2.88 ppm. It is thus confirmed that a part of the poly(1-hexene) chains have been labeled by thiophene-2-carbonyl in the form of P1 and P2. The possible side reactions of P1 and P2 with TEA during the quenching process are negligible. 1H NMR analysis on the P1 and P2 chain ends can thus be applied to trace 1,2 and 2,1 monomer insertions in the polymerization process. It is worth noting that the active sites with 2,1 last-inserted hexene unit can be efficiently quench-labeled by acyl chloride quencher, though they show remarkably lower reactivity toward α-olefin insertion than the active sites with 1,2 last-inserted hexene. The total sulfur content in the quenched polymer was measured by an UV fluorescence sulfur analyzer, and the molar ratio of S in the polymer to Ti in the catalyst ([C*]S/[Ti]) was calculated. On the other hand, the molar ratio of thenoyl labeled chain ends to Ti based on 1H NMR analysis was calculated according to Eq. (1): (1) [ C * ] N / [ T i ] = ½ I a + I b ⅓ I m × Y / ( 84 N T i ) where I a, I b, and I m are 1H NMR peak intensities of methylene protons in P1, methine proton in P2 and methyl protons of the 1-hexene units (0.90 ppm), respectively, Y is the polymer yield, 84 is molar mass of 1-hexene, and N Ti is amount of Ti (mol). The two series of active site fraction are compared in Table 1. They are quite close, but there is a systematical deviation between the results of the two analytical methods. The [C*]N value was about 15 % smaller than [C*]S value of the same sample (see Table 1). To exclude the possibility that a part of thenoyl groups in polymer are transformed to other groups not shown in the 1H NMR spectrum, calibration tests have been made to show that the difference between quantification by 1H NMR and sulfur analysis can be largely attributed to systematical deviation originated from the method itself. As shown in Table S1 of the Supporting information, molar ratio of a M3/poly(1-hexene) mixture determined by comparing the 1H NMR peak intensities of methine proton in M3 and methyl protons of poly(1-hexene) was about 17 % lower than the actual ratio determined by weighing. Tests on the effect of relaxation delay time (D1) of 1H NMR analysis showed that the [C*]N value of a quenched poly(1-hexene) sample (Cat. 1 as catalyst and tp = 5 s) determined at D1 = 1 s was 1.5 % larger than that determined with D1 = 5 s. It shows that the underestimation of P1 and P2 in the NMR analysis cannot be attributed to insufficient D1. Influence of the adjacent thenoyl on the NMR intensity of the measured methine or methylene protons could be responsible for this deviation. According to the tests, the amount of P1 and P2 determined by 1H NMR analysis should be corrected by multiplying by a calibration coefficient of 1.2. The calibrated value meets well with that determined by sulfur analysis. 3.2 Determination of other chain ends The signals of vinylidene protons have also been identified in 1H NMR spectra of the quench-labeled polymer as well as the blank polymer (see Fig. 1 and Figs S1-S2), which can be assigned to products of β-hydrogen transfer of the propagation chains with 1,2 last-inserted hexene unit (see Scheme 4 ). The signals of internal double bonds formed by β-hydrogen transfer of the propagation chains with 2,1 last-inserted hexene unit cannot be observed, owing to low activity of these species. In propylene polymerization with MgCl2-supported Ziegler-Natta catalyst, β-hydrogen transfer of the propagation chains with 2,1 last-inserted monomer unit has been found to be much slower than those with 2,1 last-inserted monomer unit [26]. The amount of dead chains formed by β-hydrogen transfers was determined by 1H NMR quantification of the unsaturated chain ends P3. On the other hand, the total polymer chain number of each sample was calculated from the number average molecular weight and yield. It was found that the sum of P1, P2 and P3 was evidently smaller than the total chain number, meaning that there was large amount of dead chains with saturated chain ends. The difference between the total chain number (Pt) and the sum of P1∼P3 was named as Ps, the number of dead chains with saturated chain ends. Since no hydrogen was introduced in the polymerization system, these saturated dead chains can only be the products of chain transfer with TEA (see Scheme 5 ). The changes of four types of polymer chain (P1∼P3 and Ps) as well as the total chain number in the polymerization process are shown in Table 2 and Fig. 2 . As seen in Fig. 2 and Table 2, the number of P1 and P2 moderately increased with time in the 30 s polymerization process, meanwhile the number of dead chains (P3 and Ps) increased with time more steeply. The number of Ps was evidently larger than the dead chains with unsaturated chain ends (P3), meaning that chain transfer with the cocatalyst was the dominant reaction to form dead chains. This can be explained by rather low monomer concentration ([1-Hexene]o =0.15 mol/L) in contrast to relatively high TEA concentration ([Al] =30 mmol/L) in the studied systems. The rather large [Ps]/([P1] + [P2]) ratio (2∼4 for both catalysts) observed can be taken as an evidence supporting high selectivity of the acyl chloride quench-labeling reactions shown in Scheme 1. If Al―polymeryl moieties formed by chain transfer with TEA could react with the quencher (see Scheme 5), the observed number of labeled chains ([P1] + [P2]) should increase with time in a much larger gradient. Not to say that if the Al―polymeryl could react with TPCC in the same efficiency as the reactions between the active sites and TPCC, the ([P1] + [P2]) value should be 2–4 times larger than the observed values, and the number of Ps would be much smaller. The low reactivity of Al―polymeryl toward acyl chloride in the quenching systems can be attributed to high TPCC/Al molar ratio (2 in this work), as alkylaluminum coordinated by an acyl chloride is expected to be strongly deactivated. There are two noticeable facts disclosed in Fig. 2 and Table 2: presence of P2 in comparable amount with P1 in the case of Cat. 1, and faster increase of [P2] than [P1] with time in both reaction systems. The first phenomenon shows existence of occasional 2,1 insertion in chain propagation. If the successive 1-hexene insertion after a 2,1 insertion immediately restore to 1,2 mode, and large number of head-to-head and tail-to-tail regioerrors are found in the polymer chains, we can say that the chain propagations have rather poor regioselectivity. As seen in 13C NMR spectrum of a typical poly(1-hexene) sample (Fig. 3 ), there are no detectable signals corresponding to such head-to-head and tail-to-tail connections. This is quite similar to the high regioselectivity of propylene polymerization with supported ZN catalysts containing internal donor [9,10]. It means that successive 1,2 insertion after a 2,1 insertion is far slower than successive 1,2 insertions in P1. There is a possibility that successive 2,1 insertions in P2 are fast enough to form long propagation chains without head-to-head connections, which form P2 after quench-labeling by TPCC. However, the absence of polymer chains with internal double bond at chain end (P4 of Scheme 4) seriously denied this possibility. It is very unlikely that a large fraction of propagation chains is formed by successive 2,1 insertions but do not undergo β-hydrogen transfer in the whole reaction process. Therefore, the presence of propagation chains with 2,1 last inserted monomer unit (P2) can be rationally attributed to occasional 2,1 insertion and dormancy of the formed P2 species. This is quite like the situation of propylene polymerization with ZN catalysts [9,10]. Based on the present results, we can conclude that the high [P2]/[P1] ratio in Fig. 2 is a result of dormant site accumulation in the reaction process. According to the results of Yu et al. on propylene polymerization with ZN catalyst [10], accumulation of dormant sites goes to ceiling level as soon as initial increase of the total active site concentration levels out in less than 2 s. In the systems of this work, the [C*] value ([P1]+[P2]) increased for 54 % and 188 % respectively for Cat. 1 and Cat. 2 during polymerization from 5 to 30 s, showing rather dynamic changes. In the same period, the [P2]/([P1]+[P2]) ratio increased for about 20 % in both Cat. 1 and Cat. 2. This means that the increase of P2 (dormant sites) slightly dragged behind the increase of total active site concentration. This could be attributed to very low probability of 2,1 regioirregular monomer insertion in the chain propagation. The high regioselectivity seems to be related with high stereoselectivity of the studied polymerization systems, as both catalysts produced poly(1-hexene) with fraction of isotactic pentads higher than 90 % (see Table S4). It is interesting to compare the [P2]/([P1]+[P2]) fraction of the two catalysts. 1-Hexene polymerization with Cat. 1 showed much higher [P2] fraction (fraction of dormant sites) than that with Cat. 2. This difference in [P2] fraction can be attributed to influence of internal electron donor on probability of 2,1 insertion of the active sites. Cat. 2 containing diol ester internal donor has lower probability of 2,1 insertion than Cat. 1 that contains phthalate internal donor. Evident dependence of active site dormancy on internal donor has also been reported in literature [10]. At this stage it is difficult to correlate these phenomena with the precise structure of active sites and the catalytic mechanism, but the new phenomena disclosed here are expected to stimulate further studies. The change of total number of active sites in the polymerization process is also worth noticing. As seen in Fig. 4 , both catalysts showed incremental [C*] ― t p trace, but Cat. 2 exhibited larger extent of [C*] increase than Cat. 1. In previous work we have reported similar increases of active site concentration with time in initial stage of olefin polymerizations with supported ZN catalyst [27]. It has been found that catalyst particle fragmentation promoted by the growing polymer chains is the main source for the dynamic change of [C*]. In the present work, the polymer to catalyst mass ratio (0.013―0.067) was rather small, which may lead to expectation that fragmentation of the catalyst particles cannot be induced by such small amount of polymer. However, the result of Fig. 4 means that even small amount of poly(1-hexene) is enough to cause evident particle fragmentation. The different [C*] increment between the two catalysts could be originated from their different solid structure. As shown in Fig. S8, Cat. 2 shows more compact surface and internal morphology as compared with Cat. 1. This difference may have caused lower initial [C*] and faster [C*] increase with time in the Cat. 2 system. It is worth noticing that the [C*]/[Ti] ratios shown in Fig. 4 are smaller than that reported in a recent literature studying 1-hexene polymerization with supported ZN catalyst [28]. 3.3 Changes of kinetic constants with time Using the conventional polymerization rate equation R p = k p[C*][M] assuming first order dependence of polymerization rate on monomer concentration ([M]), the propagation rate constant of active sites with 1,2 last-inserted monomer unit [(k p)P] was estimated using the R p, [M] data in Table 1 and [P1] data in Table 2. For their dormancy, the active sites with 2,1 last-inserted monomer unit were not included in the calculation. As shown in Fig. 5 , the (k p)P value was not constant in the reaction process, but declined for more than 80 % in the 30 s reaction period. This forms the main source of R p decay (see Table 1). Similar phenomenon has been observed in other olefin polymerizations with supported ZN catalysts [22a,27] and even with homogeneous metallocene catalyst [29]. We incline to attribute this phenomenon to diffusion limitation in chain propagation. Considering the very low polymer/catalyst mass ratio, it seems unlikely that such small amount of polymer can significantly reduce monomer diffusion from the bulk of solution to the active sites. However, if the active sites are anchored in narrow cracks of the catalyst particle, the volume of newly produced poly(1-hexene) chains will be large enough to fill up these cracks and effectively retard monomer diffusion into the cracks. When the active sites with 2,1 last-inserted monomer unit (P2) were included in calculation of the propagation rate constant, smaller k p values were obtained (see Table 1), and even steeper decrease of k p with time can be found. The rate constants of β-H chain transfer and chain transfer with the cocatalyst were determined by fitting the [P3] ― t p and [Ps] ― t p curves and making calculations according to the chain transfer rate equations (see the Supporting information for details). The chain transfer constants C trM (C trM = k trM/(k p)P) and C trA (C trA = k trA/(k p)P) were also calculated. The determined kinetic constants are listed in Table 3 . As seen in Table 3, rate constant of chain transfers by β-H shift (k trM) also noticeably decreased with time in both catalytic systems, but the decrement was smaller than that of (k p)P. However, the C trM value increased with polymerization time (see Fig. 6 ). Since k trM has been calculated by the equation R trM = k trM[P1][M] that assumes monomer association in the chain transfer reaction (see Scheme 3), time-dependent decrease of k trM strictly in parallel with (k p)P will mean that all the β-H transfer reactions are assisted by the monomer. When all the β-H transfer was independent of the monomer (R trM = k trM [P1]), we can expect that the R trM value will increase in parallel with [P1] in the reaction process. This is against to the experimentally observed descending R trM (see Table 3). Therefore, both monomer-assisted and monomer-independent β-H transfer reactions should coexist in the catalytic systems. Since the increment of C trM in the Cat. 1 system was evidently larger than that in Cat. 2, the share of monomer-assisted β-H transfer should be higher in the former. The phenomena of Fig. 6 can be taken as further evidence for the presence of monomer concentration gradients between the bulk of solution and catalyst surface where the active sites are anchored. The rate constant of chain transfer with TEA was determined based on the [Ps] ― t p data and chain transfer rate equation R trA = k trA([P1]+[P2])[Al], and the C trA vs t p traces are shown in Fig. 7 . It is interesting that the C trA value kept nearly constant for the two catalysts, implying parallel changes of k trA and (k p)P in the reaction process. Because the k trA value was determined by assuming a constant [Al] that equals to TEA concentration in the bulk of reaction medium, the decending k trA value can be most reasonably explained by time-dependent decrease of local [Al] in the vicinity of active centers. Similar to the situation of chain propagation reactions involving the anchored active centers and the mobile monomer molecules, TEA as the only mobile molecule in the chain transfer with cocatalyst (see Scheme 4) may also meet serious diffusion barrier, leading to noticeably lower local [Al]. It sounds unlikely that diffusion limitation may happen in this chain transfer reaction that is two to three order of magnitude slower than the chain propagations. This could be explained by the bulkier size of TEA and its lower solubility in the polymer phase in comparison with 1-hexene. Further research works are expected to confirm this point. Based on statistical analysis of the errors of [P1], [P2] and [P3] (determination by 1H NMR analysis) and errors of R p, [Pt] and [Ps] determinations (see Table S2 and S3 in Supporting information), the estimated relative errors of the determined rate constants in Table 1 and Table 3 were about ±6%. This precision will be satisfactory for making comparative studies on micro kinetics of olefin polymerization with different catalysts or under different reaction conditions. In summary, the method of acyl chloride quench-labeling in combination with 1H NMR analysis has shown satisfactory usefulness and versatility for kinetic studies on ZN catalysis, especially the reaction steps involving dormant sites. Since the method can be used for investigating chemical structure and distribution of propagation chain end groups in α-olefin polymerization with reaction duration as long as 30 s in acceptable sensitivity and accuracy (the average experimental errors of [P1] and [P2] determination were smaller than ±7%), it enabled us to disclose and clarify many important mechanistic problems that appear only under reaction conditions similar to industrial processes. 4 Conclusions Two kinds of thenoyl end groups are formed by quenching 1-hexene polymerization catalyzed by MgCl2-supported Ziegler-Natta catalysts, which correspond to reaction products of thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride and propagation chains with 1,2 and 2,1 last-inserted monomer unit. Amount of the quench-labeled propagation chains determined by 1H NMR analysis meets well with sulfur content of the polymer, and was noticeably smaller than the number of dead chains formed by chain transfer with alkylaluminum cocatalyst, showing that side reactions between the quencher and Al-polymeryl moieties are negligible. The active site counting by quench-labeling with thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride is found to be reliable for high chemoselectivity of the quenching. Gradual accumulation of dormant propagation chains with 2,1 last-inserted monomer unit in the 30 s polymerization process was confirmed by combined acyl chloride quench-labeling and 1H NMR analysis. Though the two catalysts studied in this work showed similar total fraction of active centers, the catalyst containing phthalate type internal donor has higher percentage of dormant sites as compared with the catalyst containing diol ester. The type of internal donor also strongly influenced rate constants of chain transfers by β-hydrogen shift and chain transfer with the cocatalyst. Rapid decay of apparent propagation rate constant and chain transfer rate constants in the polymerization process strongly suggested presence of diffusion limitation in the reaction. coredata.dc:description: Propagation chains with 1,2 and 2,1 last-inserted monomer unit in 1-hexene polymerization with MgCl2-supported Ziegler-Natta catalysts were quench-labeled by thiophene-2-carbonyl chloride, and the two kinds of 2-thenoyl-labeled chain ends were determined by 1H NMR analysis. The number of labeled chains was noticeably smaller than the number of dead chains formed by chain transfer with alkylaluminum cocatalyst, and grew with time more slowly than the latter, showing that side reactions between the quencher and Al-polymeryl moieties are negligible. The active sites with 2,1 last-inserted monomer were halted in dormant state, which lead to their gradual accumulation in the 30 s polymerization process. The catalyst containing phthalate type internal donor has higher percentage of dormant sites as compared with the catalyst containing diol ester. The combination of acyl chloride quench-labeling and 1H NMR analysis forms a reliable and easily accessible method of tracing and characterizing active sites in transition metal catalyzed olefin polymerization.
coredata.dc:title: Determination and tracing of active and dormant propagation chains in 1-hexene polymerization with supported Ziegler-Natta catalyst
